instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.SPI_MLB_MISO: What is SPI_MLB_MISO? SPI_MLB_MISO is a line between the SPI ROM BIOS chip and resistors that sit between it and the PCH. This often corrodes on Macbook Airs due to liquid damage and results in missing PM_SLP_S4_L and no bootup..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3: What is PPDCIN_G3? This is a typo of PPDCIN_G3H When you see PPDCIN_G3, assume they meant to type PPDCIN_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
threads.message:
Hello!

I have always interested in component level repair, so when the opportunity to get a liquid damaged Mac Book Air arrived, I was delighted. So bear with me, as this is my first attempt at this.

I have a Green/Orange on the Mag Safe, but no fan spin.

Below are my voltages.

PPBUS G3H = 8.58

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISN</SIGNAL> = 8.58

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.58

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> = 15.13

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3</SIGNAL> = 15.13

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.44

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.33

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.2

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS</SIGNAL> = 3.34 Pulse

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.14 pulse

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.33

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0.33

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = Pulse 2

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = Pulse 1

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> = Pulse 3

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL> = 2.3

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TBTAPWR</SIGNAL> = Pulse 3

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.7

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = Pulse .70

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.06

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5

<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> = Pulse .34

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> = 1.05

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> = Pulse 3.34

The little corrosion I found was near <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. I cleaned with with isopropyl alcohol. I measured all 16 terminator resistors and they are fine. The only issue I can find (besides the voltages) is Pin 2 on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MISO</SIGNAL>), does not have continuity with <RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR> or it’s VIA (824). My questions are… [LIST=1]
[*]Should I be getting continuity from those locations? If so, is re-soldering the chip/replacing is my next step? I know it’s a BIOS chip, so it’s not a simple rip and replace.
[*]Is 15.13 too far out of tolerance for <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3</SIGNAL> which should be 18.5?
[*]If I understood Louis's Rossmann Repair Training Guide correctly, should all of the rails be pulsing?
[*]Any other suggestions as to what I should look into?
[/LIST]

PS: PS:32 > IS:24 > Wagner 08 :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS</SIGNAL> = 3.34 Pulse"
Never post DC voltage for a pulsing rail.
Only an o-scope can show you the peak voltage there.

"Is 15.13 too far out of tolerance for <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3</SIGNAL> which should be 18.5?"
Don't bother with that; actual value depends of the charger used.
"PPBUS G3H = 8.58"
This is what you really need.

"Should I be getting continuity from those locations?"
YES, if you want to start the board.
Don't waste time in other thing, before solve tis issue first...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 42317"]
YES, if you want to start the board.
Don't waste time in other thing, before solve tis issue first...[/QUOTE]

Hello,

Thank you for this information! I had a feeling this was an issue, but did not want to chase down something if it was not an issue.

Would removing <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> an putting it back on/replacing it be the best way to resolve this issue? Or should I try something else?

I tested for continuity from

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> Pin 2 to via 824

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> Pin 2 to <RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR> Pin 2

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> Pin 2 to  <RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR> Pin 2

via 824 to <RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR> Pin 2

via 824 to <RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR> Pin 2

None of which had continuity. 

​​​​​​​<RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR> Pin 2 to <RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR> Pin 2 does have continuity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
threads.message:
Check the trace between <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR>/23 under microscope.
You can run a tiny wire to correct the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 42319"]Check the trace between <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR>/23 under microscope.
You can run a tiny wire to correct the issue.[/QUOTE]

Would the wire have to come from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> Pin 2 then go to via 824, then to one of the resistors?

Or would I skip 824?

Thank you for all your help, I really do appreciate it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin
threads.message:
I was supposing that.
You mean TP[1]<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MISO</SIGNAL>.
Is just a test point and you can run wire from it to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, or <RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR>/23, depending where the trace is broken.

BTW, "Probe: 824" (maybe Via 824 in your boardviewer) appears for all the points of that trace...
